<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 338, 415, 375]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 769, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 236, 525, 253]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 263, 561, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 537, 322]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 537, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 596, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 527, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 670, 520, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 715, 561, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 747, 578, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 777, 536, 811]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 350, 821, 368]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of the oscillations of a mass \(m\) suspended from a spring is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 375, 549, 405]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 517, 431]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is the spring constant of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The manufacturer of a spring states that it has a spring constant of \(25 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1} \pm 8\%\). A mass of \(200 \times 10^{-3} \text{kg} \pm 4 \times 10^{-3} \text{kg}\) is suspended from the end of the spring and then made to oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A small charged glass bead of weight \(5.4 \times 10^{- 5} \text{N}\) is initially at rest at point A in a vacuum. The bead then falls through a uniform horizontal electric field as it moves in a straight line to point B, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 348, 591, 367]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 819, 398]]<|/det|>
The electric field strength is \(1.3 \times 10^{4} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\). The charge on the bead is \(-3.7 \times 10^{-9} \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 410, 146, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 811, 91]]<|/det|>
A small remote-controlled model aircraft has two propellers, each of diameter \(16\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 541, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 is a side view of the aircraft when hovering.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 114, 809, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 304, 532, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
Air is propelled vertically downwards by each propeller so that the aircraft hovers at a fixed position. The density of the air is \(1.2 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). Assume that the air from each propeller moves with a constant speed of \(7.6 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) in a uniform cylinder of diameter \(16 \text{cm}\). Also assume that the air above each propeller is stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 146, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
Show that, in a time interval of 3.0s, the mass of air propelled downwards by **one** propeller is \(0.55 \text{kg}\).

State:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 532, 121]]<|/det|>
the upward force acting on one propeller

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [1]

<label>(ii)</label>

the name of the law that explains the relationship between the force in **(b)**(ii) and the force in **(c)**(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 240, 920, 258]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

Determine the mass of the aircraft.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>mass = .................................................... $kg$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 146, 430]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
In order for the aircraft to hover at a very high altitude (height), the propellers must propel the air downwards with a greater speed than when the aircraft hovers at a low altitude. Suggest the reason for this.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 144, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
When the aircraft is hovering at a high altitude, an electric fault causes the propellers to stop rotating. The aircraft falls vertically downwards. When the aircraft reaches a constant speed of \(22 \text{m s}^{- 1}\), it emits sound of frequency \(3.0 \text{kHz}\) from an alarm. The speed of the sound in the air is \(340 \text{m s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
Determine the frequency of the sound heard by a person standing vertically below the falling aircraft.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 814, 920, 832]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... $Hz$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 803, 91]]<|/det|>
The variation with extension \(x\) of the force \(F\) applied to a spring is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 102, 794, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 438, 532, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
The spring has an unstretched length of \(0.080 \text{m}\) and is suspended vertically from a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 510, 803, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 761, 262, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 761, 495, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[678, 761, 747, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 791, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
A block is attached to the lower end of the spring. The block hangs in equilibrium at position X when the length of the spring is \(0.095 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 4.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 838, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
The block is then pulled vertically downwards and held at position Y so that the length of the spring is \(0.120 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 4.4. The block is then released and moves vertically upwards from position Y back towards position X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 640, 89]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 4.1 to determine the spring constant of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 195, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<form>spring constant = ............................................. N m⁻¹ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 146, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 4.1 to show that the decrease in elastic potential energy of the spring is 0.055 J when the block moves from position Y to position X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
The block has a mass of \(0.122\mathrm{kg}\). Calculate the increase in gravitational potential energy of the block for its movement from position Y to position X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 566, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
<form>increase in gravitational potential energy = ................................................. J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 597, 148, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
Use the decrease in elastic potential energy stated in (b) and your answer in (c) to determine, for the block, as it moves through position X:
